- Vaccines have dramatically reduced the incidence of many deadly childhood diseases like measles, mumps, rubella, polio, whooping cough, and meningitis. For example, measles cases in the US dropped by 99% since the vaccine was introduced in 1963.
- Widespread vaccination protects vulnerable groups like infants and immunocompromised children via "herd immunity." When most children are vaccinated, it becomes very difficult for diseases to spread.
- Vaccines save thousands of lives each year. The CDC estimates that vaccines will prevent 21 million hospitalizations and 732,000 deaths among children born in the last 20 years.
- Vaccines also have economic benefits by reducing healthcare costs and enabling children to lead healthier, more productive lives.

However, some concerns and unknowns remain:
- Like all medical interventions, vaccines carry some risk of side effects. Severe allergic reactions occur in about 1 in 1 million doses. Other serious complications are even rarer.
- Some individuals have medical reasons (e.g. severe allergies, weakened immune system) that prevent them from receiving certain vaccines.
- While extensively studied, there may be rare side effects or long-term impacts that are not yet fully understood.

Overall, the scientific evidence overwhelmingly shows that the benefits of childhood vaccinations far outweigh the risks for the vast majority of children. They are one of the safest and most effective ways to protect children from serious diseases. However, parents should discuss any individual concerns with their pediatrician to make the most informed decision for their family.
